etymologies: early 17th century (in the sense ‘perceptible by touch, tangible’): from Latin tactilis, from tangere ‘to touch’

definitions: of or connected with the sense of touch

examples.text: vocal and visual signals become less important as tactile signals intensify

shortDefinitions: of or connected with sense of touch

definitions: perceptible by touch or apparently so; tangible

examples.text: she had a distinct, almost tactile memory

definitions: designed to be perceived by touch

examples.text: tactile exhibitions help blind people enjoy the magic of sculpture

shortDefinitions: designed to be perceived by touch

definitions: (of a person) given to touching others, especially as an unselfconscious expression of sympathy or affection

examples.text: he took her in his arms—he's a very tactile person
